reviewText:
As a game originally inspired by Prince of Persia, the Assassin's Creed series might be coming full circle with Assassin's Creed Chronicles, a series of 2.5D platforming action games that tell tales that aren't necessarily related to the ongoing storyline of the main series. Chronicles: China has greater depth than similar side-scrollers, along with an art style that gives it a unique personality of its own. While it suffers from a few quirks, it is a remarkable experience that livens up the series.

The first adventure takes us to 1526 China, where players relive the memories of Shao Jun, the last living member of the Chinese Brotherhood. It's a time of great turmoil, as the Ming Dynasty starts to crumble and the Templar gain control of the country through a puppet emperor. She's on a quest for vengeance and to help the downtrodden people of China... but mostly vengeance.

Made to look like a living painting, the art style of AC Chronicles is nothing short of stunning. Perhaps climbing up structures in the Forbidden City or running across the Great Wall of China might be more impressive as a full 3D game, but Chronicles does an excellent job representing the historic period in 2.5D. That extra half dimension means a lot, because the map may rotate as Shao Jun climbs alongside buildings. Or she might run along a path that takes her deeper into the background or foreground of the level. Getting through a level involves a lot more than just going from left to right like traditional side scrolling adventure games.

This adventure is essentially a stealth game. It doesn't dock any points for killing guards, and will reward you for taking them out without being detected, but greater rewards are given for killing only the intended targets. To this end, Shao Jun comes equipped with a number of different tools, such as a rope dart for climbing up onto ceilings, or firecrackers to temporarily stun guards. She also has a number of skills that will help her move from cover to cover without being detected.

Players can see the sight lines of all the patrolling guards. Getting through is a matter of leaping, running, and climbing without being seen. Here is where the limitations of the platforming game start to show. You can't always find a place to hide a body, and you can't drop them into water or toss them off a wall like you can in the main series. Invisible walls often keep you from stashing your handiwork. Fortunately, you can leave a body out in the open so long it's just outside of the remaining guards' sight range.

That's not to say that players can't fight should the need arise, since she carries a sword for that purpose. The problem is, Chronicles has a terrible combat system. Shao Jun can parry attacks, then follow-up with strikes, but it isn't very responsive. It's alright for taking on one guard, but you might as well restart from a checkpoint when two or more come after you. One of the least entertaining parts of the game comes when you're forced into one-on-one combat with a boss character. While the lackluster combat system might seem unfair, Chronicles works best as a stealth game. Slipping past guards is like a big puzzle, and there are multiple ways to solve it. Whether it involves silently killing everyone in your path or sneaking past them is up to you.

Even as the threats start to escalate, and guards wizen up enough to start checking ceilings and ledges for your presence, the challenge never seems to be too overwhelming. However, I did run into a few frustrating bugs and quirks. In one instance, a guard with acute senses was able to detect my movements, even though I was well out of his range. One scene has you running for your life while an entire city burns down around you, yet a group of guards would rather stand around and fight you than run for their lives.

Despite its issues, Assassin's Creed Chronicles: China is one of the most entertaining experiences I've had from the series. It's nice to take a break from the increasingly convoluted plot of the main storyline with a straightforward tale of revenge set in a historic corner of the world that often doesn't get a lot of attention in Western video games. This might not be the Assassin's Creed players asked for, but it's one that I'm thankful to have.

reviewText:
An Assassin's Creed game set in China?! OH MY!! YES!!!     Oh wait...it's not the usual style of Assassin's Creed game...?

Personally I had been craving for an Assassin's Creed game set in China, and I was very excited to see Chronicles release but it's not the usual AC game style that has previously been released, this is a side scroller, parkour run and jump glorified assault course in effect.  While this was disappointing initially, it was a refreshing change.

The art style, while not the most detailed looking game ever, it does look nice. There are some beautiful background landscapes throughout the story. Character models are very basic; at times it even looked as if some of the enemies didn't even have faces.

Each of the levels are nicely set out, you have various optional objectives to complete in each stage for extra rewards, and I would highly recommend aiming to do these as it pads out some of the story so you can get further immersed in this world.

At times the difficulty of China is very easy; there are no major stumbling blocks to be found along the way, the hardest parts for me were the melee, but since this is a stealthy assassination game, you shouldn't really be aiming to take enemies on in melee fights anyway.

The only thing that let China down would be the game length; I was able to complete the whole story mode in just less than three and a half hours. I would at least expect a five or six hour story mode from Ubisoft here.

Since the only negative point I was able to find was the game length, I would recommend China, since it is still only £7, 99, you could possibly wait for sale season to start to get a bit more of a bargain.

reviewText:
The first entry in the Assassin’s Creed Chronicles trilogy is China, and for the sake of all that is good about Assassin’s Creed, I sincerely hope India and Russia are as visually satisfying, fun and overall enjoyable as this one is.

China is a fairly befitting setting for the assassins’ style, the only thing is that there’s only one of them (Chinese brotherhood members) left: Shao Jun.
Who is Shao Jun? Well, remember that Chinese girl who went to see Ezio during the last of his days in that short film titled Assassin’s Creed: Embers? Yep! That’s the one. She went to see him to learn how to lead and rebuild her Order. Ezio is probably the best choice for that.
After being trained by none other than the legendary Ezio Auditore da Firenze himself two years prior to the start of the game, she is returning to China in 1526 amidst the crumble of the Ming dynasty and seeks vengeance upon the Templars who annihilated her brotherhood and plans to restore it.

The game is noticeably different than most others in the franchise, instead of being open-world the playable areas are offered in sections. It is also 2.5D (literally 3D but with side-scrolling platform gameplay), with some aspects of 3D gameplay, as one can sometimes access the Z-axis, which makes the gameplay interesting and adds a third dimension to otherwise two-dimensional levels. Obviously there’s free-running, climbing and parkour all over the place, and it all feels extremely fluid. The gameplay is heavily based on platforming, stealth and combat. There are hiding spots almost everywhere, and if there isn’t you can always cause distractions by cutting a rope with a Throwing Knife and dropping hanging objects, or using the Noise Dart to lead a guard away, or stunning them or simply whistling to distract a guard. The hiding spots are cleverly implemented into the level design, and when you’re in a hiding spot close to another one you can switch to and from quickly, avoiding guards and progressing faster.
But of course, things don’t always go as planned so the combat is actually pretty well executed; there aren’t counters like in other games in the franchise, instead you block a lot more and roll over enemies for strategic purposes. There’s a soft but fast hit, and a slow but hard hit. Depending on the weapon your opponent has also results in varied ways of blocking/dodging. The combat is purposely difficult, as the game’s true core gameplay lies in being unnoticed, but one can still carry out assassinations without being noticed, some of which are pretty amazing.

As for the visual aspect of the game, I can’t say that it’s extremely intense or detailed, but that doesn’t mean that it’s not a beautiful looking game in its own right. The world looks like it’s been hand painted, and filters or motion-blurring is in perfect balance with the art-style. Adding NVIDIA Physx also added to the visual fidelity and blending of everything into a seemingly alive environment that grabs you, immerses you and does not let go.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TDXtGujtbsQ

Now, this isn’t as hard-core a game as the rest of the franchise, it’s difficult, and it does require a certain level of skill and awareness, but I can’t help but feel that it’s a bit more on the casual side. That doesn’t mean that it’s not fun and enjoyable though.

In conclusion, it’s a very entertaining game, you play as a character that was barely known but trained by the probably-most-known character in the entire series, which adds a little spice and keeps things fresh. Also, come on, who wouldn’t wanna kick enemies in the face with a hidden shoe-blade. She used it in the short-film, and she uses it now.

reviewText:
Shao Jun is an assassin and her mind is set on revenge after the Templars destroyed the Chinese Brotherhood she belonged to: you'll be relying on your superior training, athletics and a small array of different weapons and gadgets to travel through levels and make sure the Templars pay for what they've done, one assassination at a time.
What follows is a game similar to Mark of the Ninja in gameplay, but less engaging overall: there's enough to enjoy in the great art style and fluid stealth but the bland story and so-so combat drag Chronicles down a bit.

PROS:

-gorgeous art style looks like an antique watercolour

-good soundtrack

-fluid controls paired with a satisfying moveset

CONS:

-bland and cliched story even for Assassin's Creed standards

-flat characters

-open combat feels a bit too awkward to be enjoyable

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=632697554

Chronicles: China is a pretty decent experience, after all there's no denying that pulling out a perfect stealth section or even just assassinating a few guards unseen is satisfying. The great art style makes levels truly gorgeous and they'd fit well in an antique piece of art: level backgrounds, rooms and character models are all very nice to look at.

The actual overall gameplay is, well, decent but nothing more: you get a few new gadgets along the way and some new enemy types will make your life more difficult but the level design and small number of actual reliable tactics make the experience a bit repetitive in the long run. Open combat is pretty meh and basically boils down to parry and then either riposte or jump over an enemy to try and hit their backs, it works but it's pretty awkward and unsatisfying.

The actual story and narrative are pretty yawn inducing even for the series and it's difficult to feel engaged when all the characters-Shao Jun included- are paper thin. The game is only 6 hours long though, so that helps it not overstay its welcome.

Chronicles: China is a decent game overall and not a bad purchase if you're looking for more Assassin's Creed and/ or some decently done stealth action: just be mindful of its shortcomings.

This is an OK game that could have easily been much better.

It's a stealth game. That's really annoying by times, especially if you're the type that feels like you've failed and that you need to redo a stage if you weren't able to stealth through everything. It is what it is - you either enjoy stealth or you don't, and this is really no better or worse than a typical stealth game. Also, it's uplay,

The graphocs options are minimal; this looks to be designed for consoles first, with PC as an afterthought.

Despite that, I had fun. When I was stealthing successfully, I was death incarnate, taking or sparing lives at my whim. The graphics are fantastic, beautifully designed to look hand-painted in a Chinese style. The score may be the best of any Assassin's Creed game yet, a wonderful blend of the familiar themes with a far east influenced style. Some of the levels are truly awesome; one level in particular is one of my favorite moments in video games this year, and after beating it I immediately retried the level so I could so I could do it again.

I cautiously recommend the game. It has big, glaring flaws, but it does some things very well, and I think that it's definitely worth it's current $9.99 price tag.

reviewText:
Video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yEicHmdt-x8

Presentation:
Assassin’s Creed is back…….again.
This time, travelling back to the Ming Dynasty, which is the last Dynasty ruled by the Hans.
The art style of traditional Chinese painting clashing with western water color is a nice approach to produce an eye catching sight whilst minimizing the lack of detailed textures and high quality graphics.
Although trying to use dull color and shadowy theme to bring out a crumbling Dynasty as told in the game description. However, in 1526, the Ming Dynasty was actually far from crumbling under the rule of her 13th emperor.  It was not until year 1586 when the 15th emperor of the Dynasty started his 30 years of absence from taking care of his empire, which was the beginning of the crumbling of the Ming Dynasty.

It is also saddening to notice the use of simplified Chinese on certain objects, for example on the flags. Simplified Chinese did not systematically exist until 19th century and it is truly a disaster for the game developer to over-look such crucial historical factor.

The settings of different stage and different sections of each stage does provide freshness with a variety of foreground objects and background sceneries. However, it is starting to get repetitive when you see the same skin of your enemies being reused. Even with various types of enemies, they are pretty much the same if you can perform a successful assassination.  The higher ranking enemies are just warning signs telling you not to engage them in the open.

Story:
Using the background story of the fallen brotherhood, being destroyed by the Templars in China. You are set off to take revenge and to restore the former glory of your order. However, as good as it sounds, this is all your adventure is about. You are not given much details of what was going on during that time of the Ming Dynasty, the historical importance of your assassination targets and what is the main cause of your action in this part of history. All you are being told is to kill someone with a Chinese name and that he is a bad guy.

Gameplay:
The combat in this game is clumsy and very punishing. Once you are being spotted, you have a high chance of being desynchronized as the dodging and blocking key combinations are just too clumsy to handle in the heat of a fight. Not to mention, how fragile our Shao Jun is. However, the sneaking and assassination part of this game is still able to shine. Being able to try different ways to achieve a gold assassination ranking is still a satisfaction.
Unfortunately, there is a lack of character customization and the AI of your opponents are yet again inheriting the illogical behavior from all previous Assassin’s Creed making you able to exploit with a set formula. It sometimes makes you wonder how these fools could outsmart the assassins in the first place.

In summary, Assassin’s Creed Chronicles: China is a game that is based on history, yet failed to tell the history that it was built on. The art style is a nice attempt to overcome the lack of fancy graphics yet the repetitive gameplay is not fluent enough to support the momentum to get player addicted to progress into the already unappealing and inaccurate story.

reviewText:
I personally do not like the game for a multitude of reasons either it being my first time playing one of these games on the PC or that I may just be absolute garbage but all in all, this game in reality isn’t half that bad. To help show what the game actually provides I’ll give you some pros and cons:

Pros:
-Rewarding Stealth gameplay as getting ‘Shadow Gold’ is not such an easy feat even on the easiest levels at times and with more points per level you unlock better rewards in that area that will help you later on in the game.

-Areas demand some forethought and trial and error to get past as the AIs are, although predictable, competent enough to check down ladders and around the area (but can’t see into marked hidey holes the game provides) and Eagle Vision is very helpful to figure out how each enemy’s pathfinding works if you get unsure of what they will do.

-Combat can be really fun once you get used to the controls as the ability to roll over enemies after counter and some fun sprint slide assassinations make more aggressive gameplay at least somewhat interesting.

-Gadgets are interesting and useful for some amusing combos during stealth as the environment can be used a bit in certain areas to your advantage.

-Controller support is present making the gameplay more feasible for people who love playing with their controllers.

-The parkour system works fairly well except at times the controls can get a bit confusing but that can be remedied with time and gameplay.

-This game runs perfectly fine on most rigs and computers that barely meet minimum settings may have fps issues at times but nothing too unmanageable.

Cons:
-No way to alter controls (I play with the mouse in my left hand making precise actions difficult at times but a controller does help remedy that issue if you have one.)

-Graphics are simplified to only V-sync, Full screen, and Resolution while the ability to alter anything else is unavailable.

-Restarting at checkpoints that have cut scenes will force you to watch it over again which will happen frequently if you try to get Shadow Gold on all checkpoints.

-Hit boxes are a bit touchy and sometimes the game doesn’t react fast enough to commands causing precise movements to sometimes miscalculate and cost you Shadow Gold especially on a long period without at checkpoint.

-Dogs are a massive pain in the ♥♥♥♥ if trying for Shadow Gold, they’re effectively unpassable blocking pickups if you’re attempting stealth. (One way you can actually get past them is to just collect the shard than restart, you’ll be sent back but you’ll keep shard.)

Those are the main points I’ve had to deal with a majority of my gameplay through the game. I can see how this game could be fun to people and for a relatively cheap price of 10 USD makes the game worth the try at least. Who knows, you might find this type of gameplay might be really fun for you or not.

reviewText:
I've played Assassin's Creed 1-3 and I'm afraid to say this, but this is the best one I've played. Know why? Because it's short, to the point, and actually encourages you to use stealth like an assassin is supposed to. I love the level design and how it gives a 3D like feel at some parts, where you can hop in and out of different planes of the environment. I love the hiding spots akin to Mark of the Ninja, the parkour parts, and the art style.

The combat is a little wonky, as heading face to face with an enemy is awkward and stiff. I'm used to AC combat being smooth and cinematic and it didn't have to be cinematic in this, but I wish it still ran a bit smoother than it is in this game. I guess it's a way to force you to only use stealth as in the bigger budget AC games you can dive into combat and easily take out 1000 guys no problem. Just hold guard and hit counter. HERE though the timing to block an attack is just...♥♥♥♥ poor awful. You really are better off using stealth kills.

I commend this game more than any other AC simply due to it's simplicity. I couldn't wrap my head around how vast they TRIED to make the higher budget AC games. The stories seemed to drag instead of take me along with them. Although the plot in this game is simple, I believe that less is more. There isn't too much going on, there's no future person you get to see hooked into the animus and so the game has more focus on the actual time period.

Am I weird or what? Little 2D game > high budget, high res 3D sandbox games? I think one thing that kills AC for me is the amount of sidequests you get that don't offer much to the experience. I've always wanted an AC game that had more focus on a linear and main story arc such as AC Chronicles: China.

I would like to see more games like this with the 2.5D environment and smooth parkour elements and stealth. If they tightened up the combat, the voice acting, and in-level side missions for the next game, it would be perfect for me.

I always thought the first review I'd ever write would be for something like Skyrim or the other AC games, but I've come to really love this game and I'm on my second playthrough now and I can play it over and over again. So, for the actual review:

Visuals:
One thing that really stood out for me in this game is the visuals. It looks like an animated Chinese painting, you can see some details really looks like it was hand painted, and some even crudely drawn, but it adds more artistic style to it, I think. The atmosphere of the game reminds me of Child of Light(which I also love), where it's like you're in an interactive storybook so this automatically rose up in my rank of favorite games.

Gameplay:
Never have I seen two guards who are so into their conversation they never notice anything else, like, say, an assassin creeping up behind them, climbing up the wall, up the ceiling, or hell, even dashing from column to column. Not that I don't like that, I just find it hilarious. As for fighting, I really love it when Shao Jun uses the hidden blade in her shoe to finish off an enemy. Also, the fact that avoiding killing and drawing unwanted attention plays a big part in this game is somewhat fresh for me. If you do kill a guard, better hide the body fast or all hell will break loose.

Others:

reviewText:
The Good
● Quite beautiful artstyle.
● Nice 'n fluid gameplay: very worthy of an Assassin's Creed title and - because you don't move in all 3d - it feels even better and more responsive.
● Well, Mark Of The Ninja. The comparison makes sense. Good thing.

The Bad
● Here be more of the Mark Of The Ninja comparison: The level design is just serviceable. It's all good looking and feeling and varied enough but there are hardly any opportunities to be clever in the way you kill or don't get seen.
● Combat. Which, imhopinion/-experience, is not completely unavoidable.

The Ugly
● There is NO Keyboard+Mouse support. If you think riding a bicycle with one arm tied to your back and the bicycle's steering reversed is not too bad, you can give it a try and mess around with some .ini file to make it halfways working. Out of the box, though? If you don't have a gamepad, just don't buy this game. Seriously.

Bottom line
● There's no harm done in getting this for a tenner. It's servicable, good-looking fun.
● Don't buy if you don't have a gamepad
● Don't buy if you haven't played Mark Of The Ninja yet. Get it.

reviewText:
I don't normally write reviews due to a lack of time but I really felt I should with Chronicles China because of all of the unfairly negative reviews I feel it's received.
It's worth noting that whereas I am an Assassin's Creed (AC) fan, I'm not a fan of sidescrolling platformers.

Firstly, yes you really do need a controller to play this game. But then there are plenty of PC games here on Steam that advise, and even require, this e.g. Dark Souls. I don't see people complaining about that franchise's need for something other than a keyboard and mouse.
Secondly, yes you do need a Uplay account. This is annoying, I know, but they do have some good games in their library. If you're looking to play Chronicles China then chances are you're already an Assassin's Creed fan and gamer, and so you already have a Uplay account, so why complain?

Pros
-Wonderful water-brushed art style that immerses you in 16th century China
-All the traditional elements from the AC series: eagle vision, syncing view points, leaps of faith into conveniently placed hay carts, assassination and distraction gadgets, lots of wall climbing, etc.
-Good, fun, and challenging gameplay that gives you the option to complete a level in a variey of different ways (remain invisible, execute stealthy assassinations, or charge in with your sword drawn) thereby giving good replay value.
-Great looking, and good feeling assassinations. Instead of having the traditional blades under her wrists, Shao Jun has blades on the tips of her boots. This combined with her martial arts skills makes for some very satisfying  face kick stealth kills.
-Combat has always been a problem with the AC games, but this one has the best melee combat by far, in my opinion. It's simple yet fun and effective in producing fun gameplay, although I wouldn't want to play the whole game as a hack and slash affair. My only gripe with the combat system is that Shao Jun's throwing knives are massively underpowered, used only for interacting with the environment. So the enemy can engage in ranged combat but you can't - not really. With a skilled martial artist assassin, like Shao Jun, it should be a case of 'one throw, one kill'.
-The best stealth AC game in the series. You really need to formulate good strategies using the envirnoment, your skills, the enemy type, and your tools, and plan your timing if you want to succeed at being an assassin and especially as a 'shadow' - remaining unseen by guards and not killing any of them.
-Nice upgrades to unlock, and it's satisfying when you do get to use them.
-Excellent speed run levels where you have to race against the clock to escape from the level. These are good fun and help to provide some nice variety to the game.

Cons
-They could have made a few more levels, especially the speed run ones.
-Controls can be a little unresponsive. I've had to press the controller buttons several times before Shao Jun picks up a dead body or rope climbs to a ceiling. On several occasions this delay has caused me to be detected and then I've had to restart the checkpoint to make sure I get the perfect 'gold' achivement. But then this wouldn't be an Assassin's Creed game without control issues, now would it?
-AI issues on rare occasions. One time a guard was looking down off a ledge and somehow he managed to see me up above him - wtf? Then another time a guard managed to detect me through a wall at a distance. I checked and double checked and there definitely was a wall between us. Rather buggy!  But hey, this wouldn't be an Assassin's Creed game without bugs, now would it?
-The voice acting could have been a little more passionate espeically considering that the story is supposed to be emotionally charged with a lust for revenge. Moreover, considering it's set in 16th Century China, all the Chinese characters have surprisingly good English accents!

All in all, I'd give it an 8/10. It would be a 9/10 if they fixed the minor AI and control issues, and I would happily have paid twice the asking amount for this great gaming experience. I'm now coming to the end of my third playthrough and I'll then be starting a fourth - mixing up all of the different playstyles and routes through the maps. I really can't wait for them to release the next two upcoming games in the series, and I hope they make a regular" AC game out of Shao Jun's story. I'd love to run around historical China."

reviewText:
Perhaps it was the moment this game was announced and launched (a.k.a. when ac unity was bumbling around being god awful) but I really enjoyed the change this game brought to an already stale series which, in my opinion, shoud have ended long ago, and I think that is what makes me have to recommend this game, if only at least that means more of THIS means less of unity and co.

Ok, so what do i like about the game... As it has been stated over and over again this game plays a lot like a mark of the ninja, a game I have personally loved and 100% in the past and in its story it involves ezio auditore's times, which mark the best games in the main series in my opinion. So far nothing that may interest newcomers to any of the two franchises, but that probably make this game earn extra kudos to those who do.

Graphically, I believe everybody has to agree that the game looks gorgeous, the setting almost does it a favour and the visuals in cutscenes are beautiful. Not so much the models, which look worse and are repeated throughout the enemies of the entire game, but you are going to be looking at them from a distance anyway, so unless you want to get nittpicky, it shouldn't really be much of a problem. Animation does the job and it is really fluid, so nothing to complain about in that respect.
The music and sound are astounding, just like a major studio like Ubisoft should offer and has done so, at least in the past, here the setting helps again and the atmosphere is set from the get go with great music and sfx.

Now to what I dislike about the game...
So, you are not going to be watching pretty cutscenes and listening to music the whole time, what you will be doing is using a controller to control a somewhat intuitive level design, which by the way sometimes likes hiding things from you with the 'annoying camera syndrome that won't let you find collectibles we only hide from you in a lazy manner' or you will be hoping you haven't played up your time to refund this game because you don't own a controller. Yes, the keyboard controls are BAD, so bad that i can't recommend this to anyone who doesn't own an Xbox controller unless they hate themselves to the point of playing dance games via hitting the dance mat with their heads.
It's not use even trying to use keyboard because by the time you get used to the controls, the game will have ended, and this is my second grape with the game. The game is not too long, and if you are not planning on finishing it while getting the achievements or the collectibles, you can finish the whole game in a longer-than-average sitting. I know this might be the cause of this game being as cheap as it is, but I think that at least some replay value, which is pretty much non-existant wouldn't go amiss.
Another thing regarding the gameplay and killing the replayability of the title is the fact that, inevitably, this game is compared to Mark of The Ninja, a game I stated before I love, and this is really unfavourable to this title. The levels are sometimes linear, there are considerably less items to use to distract the guards and there is nothing like the masks in Mark of the Ninja that complete overhaul the gameplay and the decisions you take. On the other hand, if you were spotted in Mark of the Ninja, you would just sit down and swallow bullets, as you wouldn't get any good amount of points that way whereas in this game you can fight your enemies in a system unique to this game. It's not as simple as other titles and you must be in control of enemies both in front of you and behind you, because they hit hard and you can take less hits than a piece of biscuit.
Fourth and last, the Uplay thing... yes... I know someday Ubisoft will get the fact that noone likes their service, but until then we get to eat sh*t and download Uplay.

Overall, the experience i had with the game was good, and even though it got tedious and frustrating near the end trying to collect all shards, controlling Shao felt great (after i got hold of a controller) and the whole product is of good quality. For the price I would recommend this game if you either have already played Mark of the Ninja and want something simmilar but with more of an action gameplay or if you like the AC vibe and want something fresher and cheaper than the rather duller 3D games.

Visuals:

It looks like an animated Chinese painting, you can see some details really looks like it was hand painted, and some even crudely drawn, but it adds more artistic style to it, I think. The atmosphere of the game reminds me of Child of Light(which I also love), where it's like you're in an interactive storybook so this automatically rose up in my rank of favorite games.

Gameplay:

reviewText:
After a hard-struggle period I passed all the levels of Assassin’s Creed Chronicles China. As a Chinese, I feel pleasure that the story of assassins comes to China finally, although it’s not a traditional Assassin’s Creed game. However, after I played it I still can’t recommend this game. Designers intended to create an eastern assassin’s experience through this game. Some factors are good such as graphic effect and parts of the level design. But other disadvantages lower the quality of the game, including repetitive level pace, terrible key controls, and so on. I will try to evaluate and give some suggestions about the aesthetics and mechanics. By the way, there may be expressive problems because I am still learning my English :).

Aesthetics
The Chinese watercolor style art really impressed me, which is beautiful and working well toward the Chinese theme. But the static cut scenes are half-hearted, lots of them are similar except the name of enemy on the subtitles is changed. It’s a kind of bonus for players who have passed a level with difficulty, and also an expectation to pass next level (as the players will expect to see the next cut scene if it’s wonderful). Every time I saw the same static animation I just wanted to skip.

In the matter of sound effects, the details of audio are pretty good, as all kinds of concealed weapons and hints of danger are presented well. But the voice actors seem to be impassionate, as their voices make you sleepy. The dialogues switch between Chinese and English, which really takes away from the immersion. I think using the same language, especially Chinese, will be a better choice. The dialogues between the guards are boring because of the repetition. Actually it’s a good point to show the world view of the game through their dialogues. In my view, if guards talk more about anecdotes about the eunuchs, that will be more interesting.

Mechanics
Control System: The inconvenient keyboard control is a disaster for this action game. It made my left hand cramped, and I never got good judgments in the parkour level (I got almost all the Shadow:Gold[1] in normal level). Too many buttons are controlled by my left hand, but my right hand is free at most of the time. To a certain extent, more key controls mean more actions players can take (such as in this game players can jump, hide, slide and use gadgets, etc). Moreover, more actions mean possible to create different choices and experiences in the game. For example, in some levels of this game, I can dash between the hiding places to pass the guards, or just confuse them by gadgets. I can get the Shadow:Gold in these two different ways, and the different choices have become a kind of enjoyment in this game. These different options are built on the actions players can take. But it’s a pity that they gave us a bad default control system, and never try to optimize it or let us to rebuild it.

In my opinion, the controls can be optimized in two aspects. The first one is to simplify the key controls. For instance, now we ready gadgets by key ‘F’ and active them by ‘G’, but why not use ‘F’ only? While the ‘F’ key is down, it means ready, and up means cancel. When we want to active gadgets we can press the left mouse button, it’s a more natural and convenient way as we take aim through moving the mouse. Secondly, I suggest we can just abandon the mouse in this game, so that we are able to balance the keyboard controls by both hands, such as attacking by ‘J’ and ‘K’, crouching by ‘N’(this area is control by right hand). Further, there’s no problem to take aim by the direction keys, known as ‘WASD’.

Levels: The design of some levels is pretty clever, especially the space design. In certain houses, we can stay inside the houses, or hand on ledges, or hang on the roof. It seems that we are in 3D space but it’s a side-scroll game. But the pace of levels is too repetitive, as it’s always hiding and running. In fact the game developers had tried to explore the games storyline deeper by using collectable scrolls, however this wasn’t effective since most stories were uninteresting. Although some escape levels were added, the exciting play experience was reduced by the unreasonable key controls. What’s worse, the fighting with boss, which should be the most exciting part of a game, was designed wearily. All the players need to do is to approach the boss and kill him, without any Kung Fu fighting or animation. In conclusion, the levels are boring.

Helix: In this game we can active a special Helix state—which allows dashing between hiding places invisibly. Besides, it’s impossible to active this skill outside hiding places. This can be achieved through collecting Helix fragments to fill the Helix bar. In the difficult levels in latter part of the game, this skill offers us the opportunity to rest and change the pace, and pass a hard checkpoint smoothly. In my personal experience, it’s embarrassing to keep the bar full for a long time when there are no continuous hiding places in the level. I think it will be better if we retain the existing Helix state, but adding more features on it. For example, we can active Helix at any places, and assassinate guards won’t affect the judgment of current checkpoint [2]. That will increase the chances to use this skill and adjust the levels’ pace, which makes Helix more valuable.

To sum up, the Assassin’s Creed Chronicles China is unsatisfactory because of the impassionate voice, the bad control system, repetitive levels and imperfect special skill, etc. Personally, I hope that the legend of assassins will be staged in China again, but next time we should not only be surprised at “WOW! The leading role is a pretty girl!”

reviewText:
I don't normally write reviews due to a lack of time but I really felt I should with Chronicles China because of all of the unfairly negative reviews I feel it's received.
It's worth noting that whereas I am an Assassin's Creed (AC) fan, I'm not a fan of sidescrolling platformers.

Firstly, yes you really do need a controller to play this game. But then there are plenty of PC games here on Steam that advise, and even require, this e.g. Dark Souls. I don't see people complaining about that franchise's need for something other than a keyboard and mouse.
Secondly, yes you do need a Uplay account. This is annoying, I know, but they do have some good games in their library. If you're looking to play Chronicles China then chances are you're already an Assassin's Creed fan and gamer, and so you already have a Uplay account, so why complain?

Pros
-Wonderful water-brushed art style that immerses you in 16th century China
-All the traditional elements from the AC series: eagle vision, syncing view points, leaps of faith into conveniently placed hay carts, assassination and distraction gadgets, lots of wall climbing, etc.
-Good, fun, and challenging gameplay that gives you the option to complete a level in a variey of different ways (remain invisible, execute stealthy assassinations, or charge in with your sword drawn) thereby giving good replay value.
-Great looking, and good feeling assassinations. Instead of having the traditional blades under her wrists, Shao Jun has blades on the tips of her boots. This combined with her martial arts skills makes for some very satisfying  face kick stealth kills.
-Combat has always been a problem with the AC games, but this one has the best melee combat by far, in my opinion. It's simple yet fun and effective in producing fun gameplay, although I wouldn't want to play the whole game as a hack and slash affair. My only gripe with the combat system is that Shao Jun's throwing knives are massively underpowered, used only for interacting with the environment. So the enemy can engage in ranged combat but you can't - not really. With a skilled martial artist assassin, like Shao Jun, it should be a case of 'one throw, one kill'.
-The best stealth AC game in the series. You really need to formulate good strategies using the envirnoment, your skills, the enemy type, and your tools, and plan your timing if you want to succeed at being an assassin and especially as a 'shadow' - remaining unseen by guards and not killing any of them.
-Nice upgrades to unlock, and it's satisfying when you do get to use them.
-Excellent speed run levels where you have to race against the clock to escape from the level. These are good fun and help to provide some nice variety to the game.

Cons
-They could have made a few more levels, especially the speed run ones.
-Controls can be a little unresponsive. I've had to press the controller buttons several times before Shao Jun picks up a dead body or rope climbs to a ceiling. On several occasions this delay has caused me to be detected and then I've had to restart the checkpoint to make sure I get the perfect 'gold' achivement. But then this wouldn't be an Assassin's Creed game without control issues, now would it?
-AI issues on rare occasions. One time a guard was looking down off a ledge and somehow he managed to see me up above him - wtf? Then another time a guard managed to detect me through a wall at a distance. I checked and double checked and there definitely was a wall between us. Rather buggy!  But hey, this wouldn't be an Assassin's Creed game without bugs, now would it?
-The voice acting could have been a little more passionate espeically considering that the story is supposed to be emotionally charged with a lust for revenge. Moreover, considering it's set in 16th Century China, all the Chinese characters have surprisingly good English accents!

All in all, I'd give it an 8/10. It would be a 9/10 if they fixed the minor AI and control issues, and I would happily have paid twice the asking amount for this great gaming experience. I'm now coming to the end of my third playthrough and I'll then be starting a fourth - mixing up all of the different playstyles and routes through the maps. I really can't wait for them to release the next two upcoming games in the series, and I hope they make a regular" AC game out of Shao Jun's story. I'd love to run around historical China."

reviewText: Set in the AssCreed universe, in this game you basically play a Chinese ninja trying to avenge some non-Japanese ninja stuff.
